I find it utterly ridiculous that there are people who are defending a 
family by basically saying " You shouldn't punish this families wrong-doing 
by taking their money but it's OK for the son to escape punishment  from 
said wrong-doing because of it." They used their wealth to protect 
themselves from consequences in the court of law, as such, they shouldn't 
be surprised that no one feels sympathy for them if the families wish to 
take that protection away. After-all, the families would be doing the 
public a service by taking as much of their money as possible. You can only 
suffer from "Affluenza" if you have a lot of money. The less of it you 
have, the less you have to worry about this horrible horrible affliction. 
One can only hope that the families of the victims are able to relieve the 
Couch family of the cause of this dreadful disease in the near future.

murderers)

comments.text:
The question is always, does rehabilitation make sence. This guy killed 4 
people and didnt seem very sad about it. I am all for rehabilitation, but 
what is he rehabilitated for: He doesnt know what consequences are....
Then the perfect method of rehabilitation would be, give him consequences. 
Some time in prison! Thatd show him that there are consequences, but this 
clearly is sending the wrong message to this kid. Now hes just gonna think 
"oh, i killed 4 people and only had to go to some rehabilitation center...."

top_comment.text:
Programs paid on a sliding scale criteria, means fees are based on icome.

top_comment.author: Adrienne A

comments.text:
So effectively over one million dollars every month for their company. 
Wouldn't 20k about 2% of the monthly income for that company, in that case? 
Can't they find some kind of loophole where they pay from the company and 
get a tax write-off for it?

And what about the other patients? How do they deal with such insane costs 
if not off the taxes of people who may well be struggling enough as it is?

comments.text:
+Jane Doe
The facility costs 20k per month, but they're only paying 1k per month, and

parent would.

comments.text:

comments.text:
The problem isn't money.  It's the citizens.  So many of us get angry about 
these stories, but we don't DO anything about them.  When inaction creates 
a power vacuum, it's going to be filled by some other entity.  In this 
case, that entity is the rich, the powerful, and the politically motivated. 
 And the public's response?  Basically a fart in the wind.  People are more 
vocal about Janet Jackson's nip slip during the Superbowl than they are 
about issues of any real importance.  Collectively the American public is 
stupid, complacent, and lazy, and we deserve what we get.

comments.text: affluenza
comments.author: H.M. Murdock

top_comment.text: Isn't the point of prison to rehabilitate?﻿
top_comment.author: KaeGji

comments.text:
I am a citizen who has studied history and reads the news.  I can also 
figure out that a strategy meant to heal injuries and communities is going 
to do more good for more people than a strategy where you're just opening 
wounds wider to satisfy some emotional reason.

Revenge is a race to the bottom.  You just need to read about the feuding 
families in 19th century America to see how this mentality can wipe out 
entire families and consume entire towns.

And if it did happen to me, you know what?   I wouldn't be the right person 
to call the shots because it would be difficult for me to be objective.  
That's why we have judges decide these things - a third party who is 
emotionally removed and can think clearly.

Being hurt doesn't mean you get to do whatever you want.  We must always 
think in terms of what is best for everyone.  This doesn't mean letting the 
perp go free or giving them a ridiculously light punishment - it means make 
the consequences make sense and be useful rather than be an emotional 
indulgence.
comments.author: Mark McKay

comments.text:
+Mark McKay "...driving  the prison system in the wrong direction."

Who are you to say punishment or rehabilitation are the wrong directions 
from your subjective point of view?

It's all "fair and socially constructive" until it happens to you. Ask the 
victims what they think their attacker deserves, it sure isn't going to be 
them pleading for rehabilitation.
comments.author: Tubesock

comments.text:
+Tubesock
That kind of emotional rhetoric over rare cases is precisely what is 
driving  the prison system in the wrong direction.  We should be trying to 
design a system that is fair and socially constructive, not something that 
lets insecure people live out revenge fantasies.
comments.author: Mark McKay

comments.text:
I think it was originally to punish someone for committing a crime and is 
for the most part the same reasoning today.
Would you rather punish or rehabilitate the man who murdered your mother?
comments.author: Tubesock

top_comment.text:
The consequences were someone else's death. The consequences for him should 
be a long time in prison. This really pisses me off, I should stop watching 
the videos about this kid, they just annoy me. The parents that caused this 
'affluenza' should use the money that caused it to pay the bill. I'd be 
raging if I were a Texan. ﻿
top_comment.author: Коля Адаксин

top_comment.text:
This is such crap! I had to spend 20 days in jail and a year of rehab for 
12g of pot when I was 19. I hardly ever agree with locking anyone up, but I 
have met some really nice people in jail whose only "real" crime was being 
poor, including myself. Who wants to bet we will see this kid in the news 
again 10-20 years from now?﻿
top_comment.author: Kris Sasse

comments.text:
Seriously, we need to start releasing these poor people from jail and stop 
wasting tax dollars. Even the people addicted to hard drugs need rehab, not 
jail. I'm afraid most people will always remain ignorant to the facts. The 
truth is the only reason drugs are illegal is so that the CIA can control 
the market value in america, if it all ended tomorrow and the true price 
was reflected, the amount of people out of a "job" overnight would probably 
bankrupt the country. Marijuana will always hold value because it is grown 
for 4+ months and not synthesized in a lab in a couple hours. The fact that 
things like meth are cheaper than pot is an awful thing, our government 
understands economic incentive well enough to know that poor people will 
try something just because it is cheaper. I saw this happen in 2001 when 
oxycontin was let loose on America, half of the kids in the town i lived 
with that were only experimenting with fairly harmless drugs all started 
doing oxy because at the time it was only $5 for 20mg. Once they are all 
hooked, skyrocket the price, and oops those same kids stopped oxy and 
turned to heroin because it was cheaper than the inflated oxy price. It's 
basically economic warfare, and it's disgusting. I'm glad someone can see 
it for what it is.
comments.author: Kris Sasse

comments.text:
20 years for drug possession would make me want to burn down the jail and

dr. evil shit rather than be institutionalized for a drug that the CIA 
supplies and buys from Columbian drug cartels. Even 20 days is stupid. 
Marijauna grows from the Earth, and can be even used for medicinal 
purposes! Right now some dude is down 25 years for possessing marijuana!
